:::{.column-page}
Aboriginal and Torres Straight Islander People use art and stories to communicate knowledge, passed over tens of thousands of years, about Country and organisms' connection through it. Often art and stories use to communicate this knowledge capture aspects that aren't documented or recorded in any other place, yet they carry glimpses of the past, a view of our present, and even predictions for the future.

How do these stories overlap with data (primarily collected and stored using Western means)? Do the records stored in infrastructures like the Atlas of Living Australia reflect or contrast traditional knowledge of a given ecosystem?
